author: By Melissa Clark
title: Melissa Explains It All (About Pantry Dinners)
description: Keeping a well-stocked pantry is one thing; leveling up those convenient dinners is another. Here’s how to do it.
content: If you cook, you know that a well-stocked pantry makes the job a whole lot easier and more convenient. But keeping enough rice, beans and pasta on hand for quickie weeknight meals is one thing; making them sparkle is another. My latest column delves into the secrets to leveling up those pantry dinners, and to go with it I created three new pantry recipes. Even if life is too crazy to get to the store, you still deserve an excellent dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump Raises Eyebrows by Proclaiming Himself the ‘Father of I.V.F.’
description: His campaign said the comment, which he said at an event focused on women’s issues, was “made in jest.” He has supported access to I.V.F. recently but didn’t promote it before this year.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump declared himself the “father of I.V.F.” in a town-hall event Tuesday focused on women’s issues, an eyebrow-raising nickname that was his latest attempt to claim an advantage on a matter that has become a political liability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: disseminate
description: This word has appeared in 50 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word disseminate has appeared in 50 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 9 in “Canada Wants to Regulate Online Content. Critics Say It Goes Too Far” by Vjosa Isai:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hope Reese
title: 6 Books About Nonmonogamy, Recommended by Therapists
description: These titles can offer insight, whether you’re polycurious or already exploring.
content: When Mel Cassidy first became curious about nonmonogamy, there weren’t many helpful resources. Most of the books focused on the transition from monogamy to nonmonogamy, but Cassidy, who goes by them/them pronouns, was “freshly divorced, hadn’t really dated as an adult.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Space: The Final Fashion Frontier
description: Prada and Axiom Space unveiled their NASA spacesuits, in the most far-out collaboration yet.
content: In its quest to shape the aesthetics of everything, the fashion world has extended its glossy, well-decorated tentacles into all sorts of unexpected areas: sports, film, hotels, furniture, publishing. And, as of Wednesday, space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch and Alex Goodlett
title: Female Mountain Bikers Backflip Their Way to Equality
description: Traditionally, only men were invited to the scariest and most lucrative event in mountain biking. This year, women shared equally in the adrenaline and the prizes.
content: The women were competing, finally, at Red Bull Rampage, considered the biggest and gnarliest mountain-bike competition in the world. At the bottom, Katie Holden was overcome by the moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: As Eric Adams’s Problems Mount, His Legal Defense Fund Is Empty
description: Mayor Eric Adams has spent nearly all of the $1.8 million in donations to his legal defense fund, and the pace of contributions has nearly stopped.
content: Mayor Eric Adams has a lot to worry about these days, from the five-count federal indictment against him to his dimming re-election prospects next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rollo Romig
title: Exuberant Video Game Menus Designed With da Vinci in Mind
description: The menus within role-playing games by Atlus, including the new Metaphor: ReFantazio, unfurl in a sensory feast of color, movement, sound and typography.
content: There are days when life seems to consist of navigating app menus. Sometimes it is menus within menus, as when you scan a QR code in a restaurant and struggle through a strangely complex interface to order the burrito you knew you wanted when you walked in. Good menus are helpful portals. Bad menus are annoying obstacles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: These Scientists Tested Dolphin Breath. They Found Plastic.
description: Researchers studying bottlenose dolphins found polyester and other plastics in every animal they tested.
content: Scientists have found plastic pollution almost everywhere they have looked. In clouds. On Mount Everest. In Arctic snow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin and David Guttenfelder
title: Where a Million Desperate People Are Finding Shelter in Lebanon
description: Schools, clubs and parks have become places of refuge as the displaced seek safety amid Israeli bombings.
content: At dusk, the parking lot of Tripoli’s Quality Inn is packed with cars and families milling about. Children’s shouts fill the air, reminding some of better times, when the hotel hosted weddings and birthdays parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Male Partner Cheated on Me With My Gay Best Friend. Now What?
description: A reader is eager to patch things over with her best friend and her boyfriend after they had a tryst behind her back. But should she be?
content: I recently discovered that my (male) partner, with whom I expected to be in a long-term relationship and have children, had a sexual rendezvous with my best friend, who is a gay man. My partner and I are in a monogamous relationship, so his cheating and betrayal were deeply saddening to me. But this was his first sexual experience with a man, so I can’t tell how much repression may have been involved or if I should be part of working that out. My partner and I have had a great relationship and amazing sexual chemistry that was new to me as a bisexual woman. I want to be compassionate to everyone involved and keep my dear friend and my kindhearted partner in my life. How should I approach this issue?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft
title: Judge Extends Sentence for Former County Official Convicted in Las Vegas Journalist’s Murder
description: Robert Telles was sentenced to life in prison with the possibility of parole after 20 years for the murder of Jeff German. On Wednesday, a judge added eight years to that minimum.
content: A district judge extended the sentence for a former county official convicted of murdering a longtime Las Vegas journalist, ruling on Wednesday that he will have to spend at least 28 years behind bars before he is eligible for parole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: In a Harris Ad, a Black Man Speaks to Black Men on Her Behalf
description: A commercial running in Philadelphia confronts the idea that some Black men might be hesitant to vote for Kamala Harris because she is a woman. “Women know how to make things happen,” a supporter says.
content: Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign is running this 30-second ad on television stations in Philadelphia this week at a cost of $127,000, according to AdImpact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: It’s Not Just Taylor Swift. Music Activism Gets Back on the Road.
description: Bands were sidelined by the Covid-19 pandemic during the 2020 campaign. This year, with increasing sophistication, they are encouraging political activism.
content: Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris, and Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania could not believe their good fortune.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Trump Has Turned It Up to 11
description: The former president is so dependent on racial and ethnic antagonism that without it, he would be a marginal figure.
content: Donald Trump is so dependent on racial and ethnic antagonism that without it, he would be a marginal figure, relegated to the sidelines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Barkan
title: Presidents in Movies Always Seem to Know What They’re Doing. In Real Life …
description: Hollywood’s polished leaders and legible story arcs never quite imagined the places real-life American politics would go.
content: In October 1960, when the novelist Philip Roth was just 27, he shared an unsettling revelation: Reality was outstripping fiction. “The American writer,” he wrote, “has his hands full in trying to understand, and then describe, and then make credible much of the American reality.” He ticked off examples of newsmakers that novelists couldn’t dream up: men like the quiz-show scammer Charles Van Doren; the Eisenhower chief of staff Sherman Adams, who resigned after accepting improper gifts; and, presciently, Roy Cohn, the sinister McCarthyite prosecutor who would become, in later years, mentor to a young Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson, Robert Gebeloff and Rachel Wisniewski For The New York Times
title: Small-Town Pennsylvania Is Changing, and Democrats See Opportunity
description: Lancaster County, famous for its Amish communities, regularly votes Republican. But the demographics are shifting here and throughout the state.
content: Politics came last at the 89th Ephrata Fair Parade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Brazil’s Chief Justice: We Are Saving Democracy.
description: The chief justice of Brazil’s Supreme Court, Luís Roberto Barroso, defended the court in the face of growing debate over its aggressive role in politics.
content: It has put presidents in prison. It has taken on Elon Musk — and won. It has become one of the world’s toughest policemen of the internet. And it appears poised to make Jair Bolsonaro the next former Brazilian president in handcuffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Michelle Obama to Host a Rally to Encourage Voter Turnout in Georgia
description: The former first lady, one of the Democratic Party’s most popular but most elusive figures, will appeal to younger, nonwhite voters.
content: Michelle Obama, the former first lady, plans to host a rally in Atlanta a week before Election Day, aiming to encourage young and nonwhite voters to head to the polls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Hurricane Helene Eroded Our Shared Reality
description: Climate misinformation isn’t new. But it’s getting worse.
content: How hard is it to see disaster clearly? Barely one month before a contentious presidential election, with the country seemingly divided into alien epistemological spheres, a storm sneaked across the coast of Florida’s Big Bend and traveled inland from there, ultimately flooding large portions of several mountain states hundreds of miles from the ocean and thousands of feet from sea level, crumbling highways and washing away homes, killing 234 and inflicting damages, one estimate suggests, of $225 billion to $250 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Confessore
title: The University of Michigan Doubled Down on D.E.I. What Went Wrong?
description: A decade and a quarter of a billion dollars later, students and faculty are more frustrated than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Push for High-Rise Next to Beloved Garden Becomes Battle Over Shadows
description: The Brooklyn Botanic Garden and its supporters are fighting a proposal to build a 14-story apartment building that would cast shadows on the garden.
content: Most people agree that New York City needs more housing. But in the heart of Brooklyn, a proposal for a high-rise with hundreds of new apartments has hit an unlikely sticking point: orchids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Water Dispute Before Supreme Court Gives Rise to Unusual Alliances
description: The justices heard arguments on Wednesday in a long-simmering dispute between San Francisco and the E.P.A. over regulation of water pollution.
content: The Supreme Court on Wednesday appeared to side with the City of San Francisco in its unusual challenge of federal water regulations that it said were too vague and could be interpreted too strictly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Ethel Kennedy Is Eulogized by 3 Presidents, Celebrities and Grandchildren
description: The memorial service in Washington drew major names from the Democratic Party and celebrities, including Sting and Stevie Wonder.
content: Ethel Kennedy, the widow of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and matriarch of a political dynasty, was remembered on Wednesday by three presidents, star musicians and many, many relatives during a memorial service in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terry Parris Jr
title: Teens, Do You Feel Represented in This Election?
description: As the 2024 election heats up, Headway is asking teenagers to weigh in on whether today’s candidates are addressing their concerns.
content: Back in February, when Headway first teamed up with Chalkbeat to engage with teenagers about the upcoming presidential election, one of the early questions we wanted to explore had to do with representation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Harris Will Air Ad Hitting Trump on Abortion During His Fox News Event
description: The ad features a woman from Kentucky telling a harrowing story of being sexually assaulted and impregnated by her stepfather at the age of 12.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign will air a television advertisement slamming former President Donald J. Trump’s record on abortion during a Fox News town-hall event on Wednesday in which he will take questions from an all-female audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Sex, Power, Money and ‘Mr. McMahon’
description: How decades of sexual assault allegations were swept under the rug in professional wrestling
content: In 1992, Rita Chatterton, the first female referee for the World Wrestling Federation, went on the talk show “Geraldo” to say she was sexually assaulted in 1986 by Vince McMahon, a founder of the W.W.F. and its chief executive at the time. More than just a successful leader, he helped create the figure of larger-than-life ringside hype man — the executive as protagonist — that would become a part of popular culture well beyond the world of wrestling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple and Jonah M. Kessel
title: Grab Your Calculators. We’re Going to Jail.
description: Our criminal justice system is nickel-and-diming people at every turn, burying them in punishing debt.
content: In the video above, we introduce viewers to Mike. He’s not a real person. He’s an invention, a generic character of our creation, whose grueling trip through the American criminal justice system is based on facts and real-world experiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: In Race for Congress, Republican Election Deniers and Skeptics Seek Swing Seats
description: G.O.P. candidates in critical House districts have sought to moderate or gloss over their past questioning of the 2020 election results, as well as hard-right positions on social issues.
content: Back in January, three Republicans vying for their party’s nomination in a highly competitive Colorado congressional district north of Denver were asked for a yes-or-no answer about whether the 2020 election was “stolen from President Donald Trump.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Liam Payne, 31, Former One Direction Singer, Dies in Fall in Argentina
description: Payne, who was one of the group’s standout singers, fell from the third floor of a hotel in Buenos Aires, emergency services officials said.
content: Liam Payne, who rose to fame as a singer and songwriter for the British group One Direction, one of the best-selling boy bands of all time, died after falling from the third floor of a hotel in Buenos Aires on Wednesday. He was 31.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: A French Play Explores the Enduring Allure of ‘Showgirls’
description: Inspired by Paul Verhoeven’s infamous 1995 film, “Showgirl” considers what it means to be an actress who gets naked.
content: Las Vegas was a hot location for movies in 1995. Nicolas Cage battled his demons in the character study “Leaving Las Vegas,” with Elisabeth Shue caught in the crossfire. Sharon Stone was a shrewd hustler turned mob wife in the Martin Scorsese drama “Casino.” All three actors landed Oscar nominations (Cage won), and even when certain critics didn’t care for those films, they at least respected them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff VanderMeer and Kristina Samulewski
title: We Need a ‘Managed Retreat’ in Florida
description: The Sunshine State is losing its security and safety, but it’s avoidable.
content: Florida’s two major hurricanes in the past month highlight how decades of deregulation and overdevelopment under Republican leadership have made the state increasingly vulnerable to climate change. After more than 30 years of living through Florida hurricanes, the writer Jeff VanderMeer believes a “managed retreat” is a necessary response to the growing frequency and intensity of storms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Flying Into Storms Improves Forecasts, but It Is Rare in Asia’s Typhoon Alley
description: While observational flights have improved forecasts for many storms in the Americas, such flights have been far fewer for storms that have hit Asia.
content: The storm hunters from Hong Kong braced themselves as Super Typhoon Yagi rattled their small jet. At 30,000 feet, they released probes into the Category 4-strength storm as it churned south of the city last month, gathering data many meteorologists consider crucial to improving forecasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Under Trump, U.S. Prisons Offered Gender-Affirming Care
description: The Trump administration’s approach is notable in light of a campaign ad that slams Vice President Kamala Harris for supporting taxpayer-funded transgender surgeries for prisoners and migrants.
content: A campaign ad released by former President Donald J. Trump in battleground states slams Vice President Harris for supporting taxpayer-funded transgender surgeries for prisoners and migrants, concluding: “Kamala is for they/them. President Trump is for you.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Killing and Suffering of Children in Gaza
description: Readers respond to a guest essay on what health workers found in Gaza. Also: A plea for Haiti; Donald Trump vs. the experts; many ways to be a man.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefano Montali
title: In ‘Sweet Bobby,’ Catfishing Is Even Worse Than You Might Think
description: A new Netflix documentary tells a sinister tale of a decade-long online romance scam, and the devastation that followed.
content: It started with a Facebook friend request from a man named Bobby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘The Apprentice’ Gets a Young Trump Ready for His Close-Up
description: Beyond its story of Donald Trump’s early years in business, “The Apprentice” traces his origins as a media celebrity.
content: “The Apprentice” is a movie about the early adult life of Donald J. Trump, but it ends with his birth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeğinsu
title: Ship-Free Saturdays? Juneau Votes Against Limiting Large Cruise Ships.
description: Some residents in the Alaskan capital, frustrated with cruise crowds, sought to limit ship traffic on Saturdays, despite the likely negative impact on local businesses.
content: From Venice and Amsterdam to Maine and Key West, popular tourist destinations are taking a hard look at cruise ship traffic and the crowds and environmental pressures they generate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Global Electricity Demand Is Rising Faster Than Expected, I.E.A. Says
description: A surge in power use worldwide could make it harder for nations to slash emissions and keep global warming in check.
content: Demand for electricity around the world is rising faster than expected, making it harder for countries to slash their emissions and keep global warming in check, the International Energy Agency said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Zelensky Pitches His ‘Victory Plan’ to Ukrainian Lawmakers
description: The proposal would rely heavily on increased Western assistance. So far, it has drawn a lukewarm response from Ukraine’s allies.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine made a rare appearance in Parliament on Wednesday, pitching a plan to lawmakers that he said could end the war by next year but which has drawn a lukewarm response from allies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 16, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Oct. 16, 2024.
content: An article on Sunday about the death of Viktoria Roshchina, a Ukrainian journalist who had been detained by Russian authorities after reporting from occupied territories in Ukraine, misstated the name of the organization that awarded Ms. Roshchina a “Courage in Journalism” award. It is the International Women’s Media Foundation, not the International Women’s Media Fund.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: ‘Ainadamar’ Fills the Met Opera Stage With Flamenco
description: Osvaldo Golijov and David Henry Hwang’s opera, inspired by the life of Federico García Lorca, arrived at the Met with a dizzying blend of styles.
content: It took nearly 20 years, but the music of Osvaldo Golijov has arrived at the Metropolitan Opera. And it’s not the work that he originally expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Is Elon Musk’s Brazilian Nemesis Saving Democracy or Hurting It?
description: Brazil’s top court expanded its power to protect democracy. But some are wondering whether the court now represents the threat.
content: Daniel Silveira, a policeman turned far-right Brazilian congressman, was furious. He believed Brazil’s Supreme Court was persecuting conservatives and silencing them on social media, and he wanted to do something about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Judge Blocks Hand-Counting of Election Ballots in Georgia
description: The ruling was confined to the current election, halting the measure from going into effect for 2024 while the judge further weighs its merits in the future.
content: A county judge in Georgia on Tuesday blocked a new rule mandating a hand count of election ballots across the state. Enacting such a sweeping change for the November election, he said, was “too much, too late.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,216
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Oct. 17, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Harris Makes a Broad Overture to Republican Voters, Citing the Constitution
description: Appearing in a competitive suburban area of southeastern Pennsylvania, the vice president tried to strike a unifying tone even as she warned that Donald Trump posed a threat to the country.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris on Wednesday made her most direct and expansive pitch yet to conservative and moderate voters, appearing in Pennsylvania with a phalanx of Republican elected officials who have set aside their party loyalties to try to defeat former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: Trudeau Goes on Offensive Over Foreign Interference Claims
description: Facing a revolt in his own party, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau attacked both the Conservative opposition and India’s government, which he said had made “a horrific mistake” in the killing of a Sikh activist.
content: As Prime Minister Justin Trudeau comes under increasing fire for his handling of foreign meddling in Canada, he went on the attack on Wednesday, criticizing both the country’s main opposition party and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien and Michael C. Bender
title: Asked if He Thinks Trump Lost in 2020, Vance Finally Gives an Answer: No
description: Senator JD Vance, former President Donald J. Trump’s running mate, had spent weeks dodging questions about Mr. Trump’s false claims he won the 2020 election.
content: Senator JD Vance of Ohio has been dogged by questions over whether he accepts that his running mate, former President Donald J. Trump, lost the 2020 election. But on Wednesday at a rally in Pennsylvania, he gave a crowd of supporters a clear answer: “No.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Blum
title: The Scientists Who Hoarded Seeds Even as They Were Starving
description: In “The Forbidden Garden,” Simon Parkin examines the mad, heroic decision during the siege of Leningrad to guard biodiversity at the cost of human life.
content: It’s a theatrical moment. A heroic young scientist escapes from a besieged city. At last safely in a hospital, he’s plied with hot soup and medical attention. But it’s too late: He’s too sick to eat, collapsing, dying from the relentless damage already wrought by starvation. When the nurse caring for him undresses the body, she finds a package of seeds, strapped to his chest. Four carefully preserved pounds of grain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: How Media Outlets on the Left and Right Covered Trump’s Musical Town Hall
description: When former President Donald J. Trump played D.J. at a campaign event on Monday, both liberal and conservative media outlets described it as “surreal.”
content: For about 30 minutes on Monday night, former President Donald J. Trump held an impromptu musical town hall outside Philadelphia, standing onstage and swaying to songs like “Time to Say Goodbye” by Sarah Brightman and Andrea Bocelli, and “Hallelujah” by Rufus Wainwright.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ravi Mattu
title: Shares of Louis Vuitton Owner Drop on Anxiety About Chinese Shoppers
description: Weak sales in China at LVMH, the owner of Dior, Tiffany and more, sent a shudder through the luxury sector.
content: Shares in LVMH dropped on Wednesday after the luxury goods giant warned about an “uncertain economic and geopolitical environment” and its latest earnings disappointed analysts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Victoria’s Secret Fashion Show Returns. It Shouldn’t.
description: Despite the wings, the supermodels and Cher, there’s no going back.
content: The wings were there: faux feathered, quilted, tulle, tinsel and star-spangled. So were the crystal bustiers and bras; the lacy thongs and boudoir silks. So were the superstars: Lisa, hopping off a motorcycle and hip thrusting in little bits of leather; Tyla, shimmying in hot pants; Cher, in sparkling cargo pants and a corset.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Confessore
title: What to Know About the University of Michigan’s D.E.I. Experiment
description: A Times investigation found that the school built one of the most ambitious diversity programs in the country — only to see increased discord and division on campus.
content: A decade ago, the University of Michigan intentionally placed itself in the vanguard of a revolution then beginning to reshape American higher education. Around the country, college administrators were rapidly expanding D.E.I. programs. They believed that vigorous D.E.I. efforts would allow traditionally underrepresented students to thrive on campus — and improve learning for students from all backgrounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Italy Criminalizes Surrogacy From Abroad, a Blow to Gay and Infertile Couples
description: The new law was pushed by the party of Giorgia Meloni, Italy’s conservative prime minister.
content: Italy passed a law on Wednesday that criminalizes seeking surrogacy abroad, a move the country’s conservative government said would protect women’s dignity, while critics see it as yet another crackdown by the government on L.G.B.T. families, as the law will make it virtually impossible for gay fathers to have children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: In Pennsylvania, Walz Says Immigrants Aren’t the Outsiders: Trump and Vance Are
description: The Democratic vice-presidential nominee unveiled his ticket’s plan targeted at rural voters — including those protesting his visit.
content: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, wearing a camouflage baseball cap and red-and-black plaid flannel, took the stage on Tuesday as the skies cleared on a muddy farm in Lawrence County, Pa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: 2 Men Charged in Killing of 7 People in Baltimore Gang Case
description: Prosecutors said Cornell Moore and Keith Russell were involved in a murder-for-hire enterprise with a gang operating in Baltimore City and elsewhere in Maryland.
content: Two men who prosecutors say were hired to carry out a string of killings and violence in the Baltimore area have been charged with murdering at least seven people, including a woman who was seven months pregnant, the authorities said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn and Karen Weise
title: Hungry for Energy, Amazon, Google and Microsoft Turn to Nuclear Power
description: Large technology companies are investing billions of dollars in nuclear energy as an emissions-free source of electricity for artificial intelligence and other businesses.
content: Technology companies are increasingly looking to nuclear power plants to provide the emissions-free electricity needed to run artificial intelligence and other businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Carl Hulse, Nina Feldman, Mary Wilson, Mooj Zadie, Shannon M. Lin, Patricia Willens, Brendan Klinkenberg, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Will Reid and Chris Wood
title: The Race That Could Tip Control of the Senate
description: Montana’s three-term Democratic senator, Jon Tester, is facing a tough race with increasingly high stakes.
content: Yesterday, The Daily explained how control of the House has come down to a few contests in two blue states. Today, we look at the race for the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Nebraska Supreme Court Upholds Voting Rights for Felons
description: Legislators voted to restore voting rights to more people convicted of felonies, but a dispute over that law’s constitutionality created pre-election confusion.
content: Nebraska’s Supreme Court ordered the secretary of state on Wednesday to allow people with felony convictions to vote after finishing their sentences, resolving confusion about who can participate in this year’s election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump Wants Young Voters, but He’s Nowhere to Be Seen on Snapchat
description: The former president, whose personal account was banned after the Capitol riot, has refused to spend campaign money on Snapchat ads, effectively ceding the space to Kamala Harris.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has made courting younger voters — and younger men in particular — a public pillar of his 2024 campaign. But he is conspicuously absent from one platform where they gather in large numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: New York Marathon Cracks Down on Cyclists’ Pre-Race Joyride
description: Last year, race officials say, a cyclist hit a pedestrian on the early-morning ride. This year, those attempting to ride the route will be removed.
content: Runners aren’t the only ones with the date of the New York City Marathon circled on their calendars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Trump Faced Tough Questions From Hispanic Voters
description: Also, the Supreme Court suggested that U.S. water regulations are too vague. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: During a town hall this afternoon, a former supporter of Donald Trump, alarmed by the former president’s handling of Jan. 6, gave Trump the opportunity to win back his vote. Trump turned it down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Why an Interview on Fox News Made Sense for Kamala Harris
description: The vice president will take questions from Bret Baier in a session to be broadcast at 6 p.m. She joins a long line of Democratic candidates and elected officials who have ventured into hostile television territory.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris’s interview with Fox News’s chief political anchor, Bret Baier, at 6 p.m. Eastern is, by any measure, a risk for her and a test of her ability to handle a potentially contentious interview in an unfriendly setting. This is the first time that Ms. Harris has sat for an interview on Fox, and it follows a series of interviews that the Democratic presidential candidate has given, including one to “60 Minutes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: U.N. Security Council Urges Israel to Increase Flow of Aid Into Gaza
description: Some of the sharpest criticism about a lack of sufficient assistance in the enclave came from Israel’s allies, including the United States.
content: Members of the United Nations Security Council met Wednesday to discuss the humanitarian crisis in Gaza, and every member called on Israel in speeches to consistently allow aid into northern Gaza and drastically scale up assistance to the rest of the enclave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: At Town Hall on Women’s Issues, Trump Renews ‘Enemy Within’ Talk
description: Donald Trump fielded questions from an audience of all women in Georgia for a Fox News event to be broadcast on Wednesday morning.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump reiterated his belief that Democrats are “the enemy from within” during a Fox News town hall on Tuesday billed as a conversation about women’s issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Do You Have a Hard Time Letting People Down?
description: “Put yourself first” is often good advice when it comes to taking care of your mental health. Are you able to follow it?
content: Think of a time when you had to let someone down. Perhaps you told a friend you would hang out, but then later decided you didn’t have the energy. Or maybe you had to quit something, like a sport or club, because you realized you had taken on too many activities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: New York Liberty Fans Get Creative With Jerseys, Art and Cross Stitches
description: As their favorite team in the W.N.B.A. experiences a surge in popularity, fans are expressing their love creatively.
content: Eric Trude walked into Barclays Center on Sunday afternoon wearing one of the custom jerseys that he had designed to honor two of his great loves — hockey and the New York Liberty. Nobody was as surprised as he was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daryln Brewer Hoffstot and Kristian Thacker
title: A Fading Tree, Once Majestic, Had to Come Down. But It Wasn’t the End.
description: A beloved sugar maple slowly succumbed to disease. Today, it lives on in a new form.
content: When you live a long time with trees, they become a part of you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Man Whose Fentanyl Stash Killed Child at Day Care Gets 45-Year Sentence
description: Felix Herrera Garcia stepped over the boy’s body before fleeing the Bronx day care center, prosecutors said. The same kitchen utensils used for snacks were used to package drugs, they said.
content: Felix Herrera Garcia’s wife called him on a September afternoon last year, just after she had discovered that three children in her Divino Niño day care center would not wake up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Columbia Cancer Surgeon Notches 5 More Retractions for Suspicious Data
description: Dr. Sam Yoon and a collaborator duplicated images across their research studies over many years. The collaborator has left Columbia.
content: The chief of a cancer surgery division at Columbia University this week had five research articles retracted and a sixth tagged with an editor’s note, underscoring concerns about research misconduct that have lately bedeviled Columbia as well as cancer labs at several other elite American universities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: An Advocate for Domestic Workers Wins the Just Brooklyn Prize
description: Christine Yvette Lewis is a coordinator for Domestic Workers United, a coalition that campaigns for labor rights for household employees.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll meet the winners of the Just Brooklyn Prize, who will receive no-strings-attached checks for $20,000. We’ll also find out how a man who’s in prison in New York could sway a House race in Alaska.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson and Amy Chang Chien
title: With Jets and Ships, China Is Honing Its Ability to Choke Taiwan
description: China’s large-scale military exercises are encircling Taiwan and testing the island’s defenses. They also raise the risk of conflict, accidental or otherwise.
content: The Chinese warplanes, deployed in record numbers, crossed an informal boundary between China and Taiwan. Chinese Coast Guard boats joined naval ships in encircling Taiwan. Fighter jets took off from an aircraft carrier parked off the island’s east coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Jimmy Carter Casts His Ballot for Harris in Georgia
description: The 39th president, who entered hospice care in February 2023, submitted an absentee ballot, according to a grandson. His family said he had been eager to vote for Vice President Kamala Harris.
content: The longest-lived president in American history has voted again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: The Shoe of the Season Is All Buckled Up
description: Mary Janes, whether chunky or sleek, are fashion’s favorite flat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Supreme Court Allows E.P.A. to Limit Power Plant Emissions
description: It was a provisional victory for the Biden administration, whose climate initiatives have been stymied. A challenge to the rule at issue is still moving through a lower court.
content: The Supreme Court on Wednesday allowed the Environmental Protection Agency to move ahead with its plans to limit carbon emissions by power plants, handing a victory to the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darren Incorvaia
title: Bumblebee Queens Prefer to Live in a Toxic Home
description: In an elaborate experiment, scientists discovered that the insects chose to hibernate in soil full of pesticides and other poisons.
content: North-facing, sloping ground with loose, sandy soil — if you’re a bumblebee queen on the market for a winter home, these features will have you racing to make an offer. But scientists were recently stunned to find there’s something else these monarchs like in a place to hibernate: pesticides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A Top Chess Player Is Disqualified After a Phone Is Found in a Bathroom Stall
description: Kirill Shevchenko, a grandmaster who represents Romania, has been accused of getting assistance from a computer in the middle of games.
content: A top chess player was expelled from an event in Spain this week after being accused of cheating by using a phone during bathroom breaks between moves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Abortion-Rights Group Accuses DeSantis Administration of Stifling Free Speech
description: The group behind an ad in favor of enshrining abortion rights in Florida’s Constitution says the state is violating the First Amendment by threatening TV stations that ran the ad.
content: The organization behind a campaign for an abortion-rights ballot measure sued the administration of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Wednesday, saying that a threat to prosecute television stations for running a political ad was an unconstitutional violation of free speech rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Confessore
title: A Top University Bet on D.E.I. What Went Wrong?
description: We cover the impact of college diversity programs.
content: Diversity, equity and inclusion programs are under attack. A dozen states have passed new laws restricting D.E.I. in public universities. Conservatives argue that the decades-long drive to increase racial diversity in America’s universities has corrupted higher education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Israel Allows Some Aid Into Northern Gaza After U.S. Warning
description: There was no official response from the Israeli government, a day after the United States threatened consequences if it didn’t let more relief into Gaza within 30 days.
content: A day after the United States said it had told Israel that a failure to allow more humanitarian aid into Gaza could prompt a cutoff of military supplies, one of the starkest U.S. warnings since the war began, there was no official response from the Israeli government.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘A Queer Kid in Appalachia’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: He sent me a photo of the front porch. On the left: a perfect, vibrant Halloween pumpkin. On the right: a far different specimen. Dented, noticeably lopsided, covered in warts. “No one else was going to buy that pumpkin,” he told me. “I wanted to give it a chance.” After nine years, we decided to part ways. No one is angry; no one did anything wrong. We are supposed to want the ideal. To strive for perfect in career, life and love. But he reminded me that even the imperfect can have a place on our porch, in our hearts. — Corinne Gould
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Thomas J. Donohue Dies at 86; Transformed Chamber of Commerce
description: Under his 24-year leadership, the lobbying group developed enormous clout in Washington, but he broke with the Trump administration over immigration, tariffs and the 2020 election.
content: Thomas J. Donohue, who transformed a moribund U.S. Chamber of Commerce into a lobbying behemoth and who in recent years challenged President Donald J. Trump’s policies on tariffs and immigration, died on Monday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Davis Land, Christina Djossa, Amy Pearl, Jen Poyant, Lynn Levy, Daniel Ramirez, Dan Powell, Aman Sahota, Carole Sabouraud, Diane Wong, Rowan Niemisto and Pat McCusker
title: Amelia Dimoldenberg Can Teach You How to Flirt
description: The YouTube host who has perfected the art of charming celebrities on her popular show, “Chicken Shop Date,” thinks dating should be way more fun.
content: Whether it’s Cher or Paul Mescal, Amelia Dimoldenberg can turn her “dates” at a fast-food restaurant into chemistry-fueled, revealing interviews. The dates may be fake, but viewers are always left with the impression that the celebrity guest would probably be game for a second one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Fast, Feisty and Plenty of Cancún: Takeaways From the Senate Debate in Texas
description: Senator Ted Cruz and his Democratic challenger, Representative Colin Allred, packed a lot of attacks, mostly about policy, into a quick and combative hourlong debate.
content: The fast and fiery debate on Tuesday night between Senator Ted Cruz and his Democratic opponent for U.S. Senate in Texas, Colin Allred, was something of a political throwback: a largely substantive clash over voting records and policy positions with few personal attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Mexico’s Ex-Security Chief Sentenced to 38 Years for Cartel Bribery
description: The stiff penalty was the potentially final step in the stunning downfall of the former official, Genaro García Luna, who has gone from the heights of power to imprisonment.
content: Genaro García Luna, who once served as Mexico’s top law enforcement official, was sentenced on Wednesday to just over 38 years in prison following his conviction in New York last year on charges of taking bribes from the very drug cartels he was meant to be pursuing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Jazmine Ulloa
title: Trump Faces Tough Questions From Hispanic Voters, but Largely Defends or Dodges
description: In a town hall that Univision broadcast on Wednesday night, Donald J. Trump did not directly answer many frank questions on climate change, immigration, abortion rights and other topics.
content: Halfway through a town hall hosted by Univision on Wednesday, Ramiro Gonzalez stood in front of Donald J. Trump and told the former president that he had lost his support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Michael Gold
title: Trump Escalates Threats to Political Opponents He Deems the ‘Enemy’
description: Never before has a presidential nominee openly suggested turning the military on Americans simply because they oppose his candidacy. With voting underway, Donald Trump has turned to dark vows of retribution.
content: With three weeks left before Election Day, former President Donald J. Trump is pushing to the forefront of his campaign a menacing political threat: that he would use the power of the presidency to crush those who disagree with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Leif Segerstam, Provocative Finnish Conductor and Composer, Dies at 80
description: He led his country’s principal orchestras and major orchestras elsewhere in Europe. He also mystified his countrymen with an unstoppable flow of symphonies.
content: Leif Segerstam, a Finnish conductor and composer whose hundreds of symphonies were as mysterious as his pronouncements about them, died on Oct. 9 in Helsinki. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: A Weary Trump Whips Up Anger in Atlanta
description: At a rally in a state he lost in 2020, the former president considered the possibility of another defeat.
content: The ex-president, exhausted at last?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: England Entrusts a National Treasure to (Gasp!) a German
description: The appointment of Thomas Tuchel to coach the England men’s national soccer team has provoked, well, some strong feelings.
content: The post of coach of the England men’s national soccer team has long been described — with only a hint of exaggeration — as the second-most important job in the country. In terms of prestige, significance and pressure, the theory goes, it is outstripped only by the even more thankless task of being prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: In Dallas, an Entire Dance Troupe Was Fired. Now They’re Protesting.
description: Former artists of Dallas Black Dance Theater say they were dismissed in retaliation for forming a union. The company denies the accusation.
content: The renowned Dallas Black Dance Theater opened its 48th season with a showcase of African dance on Friday. It should have been a night of celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Bashes Trump’s Bizarre Town Hall
description: Kimmel joked on Tuesday that Trump “just said ‘To hell with it’ and started asking his tech guys to play songs off his iPad.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Thompson
title: What Teenagers Told Us About Their Faith in U.S. Politics
description: Most teens who responded to the Headway Election Challenge thought a vote could make a difference, but they don’t trust the overall system to address issues that matter to them.
content: Norah Henry has a clear memory of the days after the 2020 presidential election. The race in Georgia, her home state, had been so close that the votes had to be tallied three times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Pentagon to Give Honorable Discharges to Some Kicked Out Under ‘Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell’
description: More than 800 service members administratively separated from the military under the now-repealed policy will receive discharge upgrades.
content: The Pentagon announced on Tuesday that more than 800 service members who were kicked out of the military under the now-repealed “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy will receive honorable discharge upgrades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders and Annie Correal
title: Substitute Teacher Reenacted George Floyd Murder at Minnesota High School
description: Students said the teacher, who claimed to be a police officer, also said “police brutality isn’t real.”
content: A Minnesota high school is investigating reports that a substitute English teacher reenacted the murder of George Floyd, restraining a student during class, an email sent to parents and shared with The New York Times said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: Exhibition Recreating Anne Frank’s Secret Annex to Open in New York
description: For the first time, the Anne Frank House in Amsterdam will replicate the cramped rooms where Frank and her family spent two years hiding to evade Nazi capture.
content: It will soon be possible to experience in New York City the haunting atmosphere of the secret annex, the warren of narrow, shadowy rooms where Anne Frank wrote her diary. On Wednesday, the Anne Frank House in Amsterdam, the museum containing the annex where Frank, her family and four other Jews took refuge from the Nazis, is to announce the winter opening of “Anne Frank the Exhibition,” which will feature the first full-scale re-creation of the hiding place on foreign soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: 2 Missing After Navy Fighter Jet Crashes Near Mount Rainier
description: The two crew members who were onboard the aircraft remain missing, Navy officials said, after it crashed during a routine training flight.
content: Searchers were looking on Wednesday for two crew members who had been onboard a Navy aircraft that crashed near Mount Rainier in Washington State during a training flight a day earlier, according to Navy officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: Georgia Prosecutor Seeks to Reinstate Quashed Charges in Trump Elections Case
description: The appeal filed on Tuesday disputes a judge’s ruling that six of the charges brought against Donald J. Trump and his allies in Georgia were not specific enough.
content: The prosecutor overseeing the election interference case against Donald J. Trump in Georgia has asked an appeals court to restore six charges that a judge had dismissed in the case, including one related to a call that Mr. Trump made to Georgia’s secretary of state in January 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Announces $425 Million in Aid to Ukraine
description: President Biden spoke by telephone to President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine about the security package, which includes munitions, armored vehicles and other weapons.
content: President Biden surged $425 million to Ukraine’s defense against Russia on Wednesday as he prepared to travel to Germany to celebrate the unified front of Western allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: In This Small Maine County, the Sheriff’s Race Is Haunted by a Mass Shooting
description: The race has become a referendum on what the Sagadahoc County Sheriff’s Office did, and failed to do, before a shooting that killed 18 people in Lewiston last fall.
content: In an alternate reality — one in which a mentally unstable gunman did not kill 18 people in Lewiston, Maine, last October — the biggest issue in the race for Sagadahoc County sheriff this fall might have been the budget for the county jail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa McCarty
title: Afraid of Flying? Here’s How to Make It Feel Less Scary.
description: Fear of flying affects more than 25 million Americans. If you are among them, these tools and expert tips could help make your next plane ride easier.
content: More than 25 million Americans have a severe fear of flying, or aerophobia, the Cleveland Clinic estimates. Aerophobia can cause extreme anxiety before and during a flight as the amygdala, the brain’s emotional center, goes into overdrive over perceived dangers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: The Perfect Stew for Fall Doesn’t Have to Be Perfect
description: This squash stew, rich with sharp tamarind and creamy coconut, is meant to restore.
content: It strikes me, not for the first time, that the simple things in life can be the most complicated. If something is flagged as complicated or paradoxical, then we’re geared up for nuance. It’s the apparently straightforward things that are anything but.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Bienstock
title: Eddie Van Halen Changed Rock History. Now His Brother Is Telling Their Story.
description: The guitarist and drummer formed the core of the powerhouse band. After Eddie died of cancer in 2020, Alex stayed quiet, but he’s breaking his silence in a new book.
content: On Oct. 4, 2015, Van Halen performed at the Hollywood Bowl in what proved to be its last show, capping a decades-long run as one of rock’s most successful and influential acts. The amphitheater is about 30 minutes from the 800-square-foot house in Pasadena, Calif., where the Van Halen brothers — the drummer Alex and the guitarist Eddie — grew up. But the journey between those spots took the group all over the world, through the highest highs and lowest lows of rock ’n’ roll glory, excess and tragedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ismail Auwal and Elian Peltier
title: Fuel Tanker Explosion Leaves at Least 150 Dead in Nigeria
description: Residents of a nearby town went to scoop up gasoline that had spilled from an overturned tanker, but then it exploded, setting off an inferno. Several similar disasters have taken place in recent years.
content: More than 150 people were killed in northern Nigeria on Tuesday after an overturned fuel tanker exploded, according to a police spokesman, in one of the deadliest road disasters ever recorded in Africa’s most populous country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: Paul Rudolph Was an Architectural Star. Now He’s a Cautionary Tale.
description: His Brutalist buildings, praised during the Kennedy era, are now being demolished. A new exhibition in Manhattan looks at the limits of genius.
content: American architecture’s bright, shining light of the Kennedy era, Paul Rudolph was scrounging for commissions less than a decade later. He may now be best remembered — to the extent his name rings bells — for the heroic, bush-hammered concrete Camelot he designed during the early 1960s to house the architecture school at Yale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Thursday Briefing: Trump Threatens ‘the Enemy From Within’
description: Plus, the women of the world’s gnarliest mountain-bike competition.
content: Donald Trump is pushing a menacing political threat to the forefront of his campaign before the Nov. 5 election: that he would use the power of the presidency to crush those who disagree with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sonja B. Starr
title: Critics of Affirmative Action Say This Year’s Admissions Data Are Fishy. They’re Not.
description: There are perfectly legal explanations for why schools’ demographics might not change after the fall of affirmative action.
content: As universities have released demographic information about their new freshman classes — the first cohort affected by last year’s Supreme Court decision banning affirmative action — advocates for colorblindness are crying foul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Water Crises Threaten the World’s Ability to Eat, Studies Show
description: Food production is concentrated in too few countries, many of which face water shortages, the researchers said.
content: High food prices, meet the global water crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Moritz
title: The Progressive Politicians Who Failed San Francisco
description: Aaron Peskin, a little-known progressive politician, bears responsibility for some of San Francisco’s biggest problems.
content: Republicans who attack the Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris as a San Francisco radical who is responsible for the destruction of the city must be unfamiliar with the species. Ms. Harris, who cut her teeth confronting murderers and rapists, left the city at least a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal K. Katyal
title: In Case of an Election Crisis, This Is What You Need to Know
description: We have just a short time to understand the challenges across state legislatures, Congress, executive branches and elected judges.
content: In 2020, when Donald Trump questioned the results of the election, the courts decisively rejected his efforts, over and over again. In 2024, the judicial branch may be unable to save our democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jeanna Smialek
title: Trump and Harris Push Economic Plans to Woo Holdouts
description: The candidates provided more detail on how they would bolster the economy, with ideas ranging from tariffs to more assistance for Black entrepreneurs.
content: With the presidential race virtually a dead heat, Vice President Kamala Harris and Donald Trump on Tuesday zeroed in on voters who could swing the outcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: TikTok’s Owner Already Publishes Digital Books. Now It Is Moving Into Print.
description: ByteDance, the Chinese tech giant that owns TikTok, will focus its publisher, 8th Note Press, on popular genres such as romance, romantasy and young adult fiction.
content: ByteDance, the Chinese technology giant that owns TikTok, made an initial move into publishing digital books last year. Now the company’s publishing imprint, 8th Note Press, is planning to significantly expand its retail footprint by publishing print editions and selling them in physical bookstores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in Colorado, Virginia and Washington, D.C.
description: A Craftsman-style house from 1906 in Denver, a turn-of-the-century townhouse in Washington, D.C., and a Queen Anne Revival-style house in Fredericksburg, Va.
content: This six-bedroom, five-and-a-half-bath home was once owned by Antoinette Perry, the actress after whom Broadway’s Tony Awards were named. It is in Morgan’s Historic District, where wide streets are lined with Craftsman, Mediterranean Revival and Tudor Revival mansions. Two of Denver’s most popular public spaces are within walking distance: Cheesman Park, home to the Denver Botanic Gardens, and Congress Park, which has a playground, soccer fields and a swimming pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 494
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Oct. 17, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Into the Gender Gap
description: Harris and Trump are trying to address the gender gap. Their approaches could not be more different.
content: If you have been reading this newsletter with any regularity (and I’m grateful that you have), you’ll know by now that this whole election might just turn on gender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: Has a Celebrity Interview Made You Cringe? It Was Probably Hers.
description: Kjersti Flaa’s awkward interviews with Blake Lively and Anne Hathaway from years ago blew up online. She may release more because “the times are a little different.”
content: Kjersti Flaa says she never intended for her uncomfortable encounter with Blake Lively to get so much attention. Ms. Flaa, a Norwegian journalist who is based in Los Angeles, had been having a conversation with a fellow Norwegian reporter about celebrity interviews gone wrong when her conversation with Ms. Lively, which took place during the 2016 press junket for the movie “Café Society,” came to mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: In ‘Vladimir,’ a Russian Reporter’s Fight Is an Apt Election Season Tale
description: The writer Erika Sheffer takes a big swing in a Manhattan Theater Club production examining “the point at which a society finds itself on the brink.”
content: For Raya Bobrinskaya, a hard-nosed newspaper journalist in Vladimir Putin’s Russia, being poisoned is a hazard of the job. She almost expects it to happen to her at some point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat and Carlos Lozada
title: Antichrists, Chain Saws and Natalism: A Very ‘M.O.O.’ Halloween Episode
description: The hosts share their favorite scary movies, books and television series.
content: Michelle Cottle loves Halloween, Ross Douthat watches horror movies against his will, and Carlos Lozada is making textual comparisons across satanic franchises. It’s a very “Matter of Opinion” Halloween bonus episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: Israeli Strike Hits Lebanese Municipal Building, Killing Mayor
description: The strike, in the south of Lebanon, killed at least 16 people, Lebanese officials said. Israel, which also struck near Beirut, said it was targeting Hezbollah militants.
content: The Israeli military on Wednesday bombed the densely populated southern outskirts of Beirut for the first time in days and also struck a southern Lebanese city where local officials were meeting, killing at least 16 people, including the mayor, according to Lebanese officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Claire Moses
title: Paul Lowe, Award-Winning British Photojournalist, Dies at 60
description: He was killed in a stabbing near Los Angeles, and his 19-year-old son was arrested, the authorities said. Mr. Lowe had earned acclaim for documenting the siege of Sarajevo and other conflicts.
content: Paul Lowe, an award-winning British photojournalist who captured the horror of war during the fall of the former Yugoslavia in a career that spanned decades and continents, was killed in a stabbing near Los Angeles on Saturday. He was 60.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett
title: Two Key Prosecutors in Trump Documents Case Leave Special Counsel’s Office
description: The departures amount to a tacit acknowledgment that any trial in that case will not happen for many months, if not years.
content: Two veteran prosecutors who had key roles in the special counsel Jack Smith’s pursuit of classified documents charges against former President Donald J. Trump have left Mr. Smith’s office, people familiar with the move said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: In a Decade-long Caper, Criminals Cashed In on Fake Wine, Police Say
description: A criminal network was accused of selling bottles of fake French wine for as much as 15,000 euros. It’s the latest in a growing criminal trend: wine fraud.
content: The red French wines were some of the most high-end bottles you could find, stacked neatly among other luxury labels. They appeared in 2019 on the top shelves of wine merchants in Italy and Switzerland, catering to wealthy customers and their finer palates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: A Crowd of Republicans Will Join Harris at a Pennsylvania Stop
description: The visit will take place near the Revolutionary War site where George Washington crossed the Delaware.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris will continue her explicit outreach to Republican voters on Wednesday at a Pennsylvania event with a phalanx of former Republican elected officials who have turned against former President Donald J. Trump, the Harris campaign said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Agrawal
title: More Research Links IUDs to Breast Cancer Risk
description: A new study adds to the evidence on hormonal contraceptives and breast cancer. But experts stressed the overall risk remains low.
content: A study published Wednesday found that women using contraceptive intrauterine devices that deliver a certain hormone are at increased risk of breast cancer, though risk of the disease in these women remained low overall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: A warning from the U.S. to Israel.
content: In a letter to top Israeli officials, the U.S. warned Israel to increase the flow of humanitarian supplies into the Gaza Strip within 30 days or risk losing military aid, U.S. officials said. American law forbids giving military aid to any country found to be blocking the delivery of U.S.-provided humanitarian supplies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Trump Preaches to His Women’s Choir
description: Remaining persuadable voters are unlikely to be swayed by this late-breaking swerve toward the center.
content: If you were an alien who touched down from outer space knowing nothing about American politics and you were forced to watch Donald Trump’s women-only town hall on Fox News on Wednesday morning, you could easily be bamboozled into thinking that Trump holds the sort of women-friendly family policy positions long championed by Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea, Longing for Battle Experience, Eyes Ukraine
description: Helping Russia in the war is an opportunity for North Korea to test its new weapons, and Ukrainian officials say the North’s troops are also gaining direct battle experience.
content: The war in Ukraine is providing North Korea’s military with something it has long hoped for: opportunities to test its new weapons and its officers’ preparedness for modern warfare, analysts and officials in South Korea said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Hair You Won’t Soon Forget
description: The diversity of hairstyles at fashion weeks has grown to rival the range of clothes worn on and off the runway.
content: With all the attention paid to clothes seen at fashion weeks, it can be easy to overlook the handiwork of hairstylists and barbers. But as hair becomes as integral to personal style as clothing, the diversity of eye-catching hairstyles has grown to rival the breadth of apparel and accessories worn by models and people in the street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Can I Patronize a Place Run by a Trump Supporter?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what it means to be a customer of someone who espouses a radically different political perspective.
content: For 18 months, I’ve taken a weekly lesson at a stable that specializes in therapeutic work. The team here helps disabled people experience horseback riding and nonmounted equine exercises; they also have a kids’ program. The barn is truly my happy place, so much so that I have volunteered at its events and made small financial contributions to the program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam and Dani Blum
title: Ananda Lewis, Former MTV V.J., Says She Has Stage 4 Breast Cancer
description: Lewis, the host of the 1990s MTV show “Hot Zone,” tried to fight her illness without undergoing a double mastectomy. She says she is responding well after resuming treatment.
content: The former MTV V.J. Ananda Lewis said in a CNN round-table discussion that was posted online on Tuesday that her breast cancer, which she first learned she had in 2019, metastasized last year and had reached Stage 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Can Remote Workers Reverse Brain Drain?
description: Researchers found that when remote workers were paid to move to Tulsa, Okla., everyone came out ahead.
content: Business leaders and local officials in Tulsa, Okla., puzzled for years over how to fill the hole created when young people left for big coastal cities. What, they wondered, could keep professionals rooted in the heartland?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Michael Crowley, Alissa J. Rubin, Robert Jimison and Jessica Metzger
title: Early Votes Pour In, and a U.S. Warning to Israel Over Gaza
description: Plus, the new hot item on wedding registries.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Takes On Campaign Duty in Pennsylvania, Celebrating Unions
description: As Jill Biden and JD Vance also made stops around Philadelphia, the president’s visit highlighted the intense struggle to persuade voters in what may be the most critical swing state.
content: President Biden and Jill Biden, the first lady, joined the pitched electoral struggle over Pennsylvania on Tuesday, fanning out with three appearances across the Philadelphia area intended to aid Vice President Kamala Harris in what may be the most consequential swing state.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: THEIR PASSION AND PAIN
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, October 16, 2024
content: “It would be nice to be the first to do it, wouldn’t it? Go down in the history books.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Why Us vs. Them Is Not Such a Bad Way to See the World
description: Two new books by psychologists explore the roots of group identity, arguing that it is natural and potentially useful — even in polarized times.
content: When it comes to how our minds work, people have a lot in common, but instead of bringing us together, our shared traits are doing a remarkably effective job of tearing us apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Colon
title: 4 Charged With Running Prostitution Ring on Long Island
description: A Suffolk County police officer and a high school teacher are among four people accused of operating brothels, prosecutors said.
content: Four people, including a police officer and a high school teacher, have been charged with running a prostitution ring that operated two brothels on Long Island over nearly five years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: When Patriarchy Trumps Race
description: Despite his flaws, the former president’s ideas and style appeal to some Black men.
content: For over a year, as I’ve talked to Black men and voting organizers, I’ve picked up on discontent with the Democratic Party from some Black men, but I wasn’t sure what to make of it or how widely that sentiment stretched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Oreskes
title: Trump Draws, and Repels, Nevada Latinos With His Anti-Immigrant Message
description: For some, Donald J. Trump’s incessant attacks on immigrants are too much. Still, many appear prepared to look past his escalations and back a candidate they believe will help their livelihoods.
content: Two months ago, Javier Barajas hosted former President Donald J. Trump at Il Toro E La Capra, one of five restaurants he owns in Las Vegas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: For Ruben Gallego, the Campaign Trail Runs Through the Grand Canyon
description: The Democratic congressman, who is running for Senate in Arizona, hiked thousands of feet down to meet the Havasupai, a Native tribe, on their land, part of an extensive outreach effort in a competitive race.
content: It was almost exactly three weeks until Election Day, and Representative Ruben Gallego was tramping his way through the red dust of the Grand Canyon, determined to make it down 3,000 feet to the bottom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Hurricanes Spur Pet Adoptions Nationwide. Should You Get a ‘Storm Dog’?
description: Amid major disasters, shelter animals are often sent to other states. And people are more likely to foster and adopt. Here’s what to know.
content: Just days after Hurricane Milton hit Florida last week, about a dozen shelter dogs from a small town in Hendry County had already been flown to Texas. Several dozen other animals, from Pinellas County, had been taken by truck to shelters in Massachusetts and New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Big Money Flowed to Pro-Trump Groups in the Past Three Months
description: Three people — Elon Musk, Miriam Adelson and Dick Uihlein — put a combined $220 million into groups supporting Donald J. Trump in July, August and September.
content: Quite a bit happened in presidential politics this summer. But the money behind much of it has been somewhat hidden — until now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Making Room for ‘Cosmopolitan Plants’ Among Native Species
description: The landscape designer Donald Pell believes using a wider palette with nonnatives from around the world can add joy to gardens.
content: The naturalistic landscapes that Donald Pell creates meet with approval from such discerning constituents as pollinators and birds, and seeing and hearing their feedback delights him in return.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Hanh Huynh’s puzzle is a lesson in patience.

author: By Vimal Patel and Sharon Otterman
title: Columbia Bars Vocal Pro-Israel Professor From Campus
description: The university said Shai Davidai had repeatedly harassed and intimidated employees. He said the university had not done enough to crack down on pro-Palestinian protests.
content: Columbia University has temporarily barred a vocal pro-Israel professor from campus, saying he repeatedly harassed and intimidated the school’s employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Richard V. Secord, Middleman in Iran-Contra Scandal, Is Dead at 92
description: A war hero and a former Air Force general, he denied wrongdoing for his role in the Reagan-era shipment of arms to Iran to support Nicaraguan rebels.
content: Richard V. Secord, a former Air Force general and C.I.A. operative who was the logistical middleman in the Iran-contra scandal that rocked the Reagan administration with illegal arms sales to Iran to support right-wing rebels in Nicaragua, died on Tuesday. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Five Takeaways From Kamala Harris’s Interview With Charlamagne Tha God
description: During a free-flowing interview that was by turns friendly and pointed, the vice president went beyond her previous remarks in casting Donald Trump as an authoritarian.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris agreed on Tuesday with the radio host Charlamagne Tha God that former President Donald J. Trump was a fascist, going a step further than she had before in casting her Republican rival as a dangerous authoritarian leader.
source.name: The New York Times

title: These 9 Women Were Solidly With Trump. Here’s What Has Changed.
description: The participants discuss how Kamala Harris’s entry into the race changed — or didn’t change — their thinking about the election.
content: The participants discuss how Kamala Harris’s entry into the race changed — or didn’t change — their thinking about the election.

title: Elon Musk Is Going All In to Elect Donald Trump

Theodore Schleifer, who covers campaign finance and billionaires for The New York Times, explains how Musk, who owns the social network X, is working to re-elect former President Donald J. Trump.
